description:

- Simpler invocation (no --auto flag)

5. **QA checkpoints** - Run tabz-manager between waves (parallel with merge/setup)
6. **Context monitoring** - At 70%, /wipe with handoff to continue
7. **Bug creation** - QA issues added to backlog automatically

Run tabz-manager in parallel with merge/worktree setup:
- Start dev server
- Screenshot desktop/tablet/mobile
- Check console errors
- Create bug issues if problems found
- Bugs picked up in next wave

## Self-Recovery
After /wipe, handoff contains:
```markdown
## Auto-Swarm in Progress
Wave N processing. Run `/bd-swarm-auto` to continue.
```
Beads has full state - just resume.

title: Watcher: reuse low-context workers for follow-up tasks
description:
When a worker completes a task with low context usage (<50%), don't kill them. Instead:

1. Detect completion + check context % from tmuxplexer/state
2. If context < 50%, check `bd ready` for related unblocked issues
3. Send next task to same worker via tmux send-keys
4. Only kill when context >= 50% or no related tasks available

## Benefits
- Workers already have skills/plugins loaded
- CLAUDE.md and codebase understanding preserved
- Faster task completion (no cold start)
- More efficient token usage

## Related task detection
Could match by:
- Same component/area (inferred from file paths)
- Same type (feature, bug, task)
- Explicit `related_to` field in beads
- Priority order if no better match

## Implementation
Update watcher.md pipeline:
```
WORKER_DONE + context < 50%:
  â†’ Check bd ready for related tasks
  â†’ If found: send new task prompt
  â†’ If none: proceed to cleanup

WORKER_DONE + context >= 50%:
  â†’ Proceed to cleanup (worker is tired)
```

title: Subagent skills: frontmatter loads full skill content instead of progressive disclosure
description:
When spawning subagents with `skills:` frontmatter, the full content of every listed skill is loaded into context immediately. This causes agents to start with 30-40k tokens used before doing any work.

Expected behavior per CLAUDE.md:
- Skills load as ~200 tokens until invoked
- Full content loads only when skill is actually used

Current behavior:
- All skills in frontmatter are fully expanded into context at spawn time
- This defeats the purpose of progressive disclosure
design:
## Root Cause

This is a **Claude Code platform-level issue**, not fixable in plugin code.

The `skills:` YAML frontmatter in agents is parsed by Claude Code when spawning agents. The platform loads **full skill content** instead of ~200 token stubs.

## Affected Conductor Agents

| Agent | Skills | Expected Tokens | Actual Tokens |
|-------|--------|-----------------|---------------|
| prompt-drafter | sequential-thinking | ~200 | ~5000+ |
| tabz-artist | canvas-design, mermaidjs-v11 | ~400 | ~15000+ |
| prompt-engineer | sequential-thinking | ~200 | ~5000+ |

## Code Path (Claude Code internals)

```
when spawning agent:
  read agent.md file
  parse YAML frontmatter
  get skills: [skill-name]
  
  for each skill:
    lookup skill file
    // BUG: Should load stub (~200 tokens)
    // ACTUAL: Loads full SKILL.md content
    include_in_context(full_skill_content)  // WRONG
```

## Plugin-Level Workaround

Since we cannot fix Claude Code internals:
1. Remove `skills:` frontmatter from affected agents
2. Document in agent system prompt which skills to invoke
3. Agents call skills via `Task(skill: "name")` when needed

This sacrifices the declarative `skills:` pattern but achieves the same token savings.
acceptance_criteria:
- Subagents with skills: frontmatter start with <5k tokens from skills
- Full skill content only loads when skill is invoked
- No regression in skill functionality when invoked
notes:
## Resolution (2026-01-08)

**Resolved by architectural change** - removed the subagent pattern entirely instead of fixing the `skills:` frontmatter loading bug.

### Changes Made

1. **Disabled subagents plugin** - Set `subagents@my-plugins: false` in settings.json
2. **Removed duplicate skills/** - Deleted 55MB / 590 files from my-plugins
3. **Reverted conductor to skill-aware prompts** - Workers invoke skills directly (e.g., `/xterm-js`) instead of through subagents
4. **Updated conductor docs** - bd-swarm.md, bd-swarm-auto, worker-architecture.md now use skill hints pattern

### Commits

- `my-plugins@4451fff` - refactor: remove duplicate skills/ directory
- `TabzChrome@4fac77a` - refactor(conductor): revert to skill-aware prompts, remove subagent worker pattern

### Token Results

| Metric | Before | After |
|--------|--------|-------|
| Custom agents | 1.4k tokens | 660 tokens |
| Total context | 35k tokens | 27k tokens |

### Why This Approach

The subagent pattern (frontend-builder, backend-builder, etc.) created a 3-layer context explosion:
1. Worker loads
2. Worker invokes subagent
3. Subagent invokes skills

By having workers invoke skills directly, we eliminate the middle layer and avoid the `skills:` frontmatter bug entirely.

title: Conductor: poll tmuxplexer pane instead of watcher subagent
description:
## Current Problem
The watcher is a separate subagent that:
- Burns context on monitoring
- Detected stuck workers but didn't nudge properly
- Would incorrectly nudge workers waiting on AskUserQuestion

## Simpler Approach
Remove watcher subagent. Conductor monitors via background window in its own session.

### 1. Spawn tmuxplexer in background window
```bash
# TabzChrome windows start at 1
# Window 1: conductor/claude (main)
# Window 2: tmuxplexer --watcher (background monitor)

# Check if monitor window exists, create if not
if ! tmux list-windows -F '#{window_name}' | grep -q "^monitor$"; then
  tmux new-window -d -n "monitor" "tmuxplexer --watcher"
fi
```

User can click status bar to switch to monitor window if they want to see it.

### 2. Periodic pane capture (every ~2 min)
```bash
tmux capture-pane -t ":monitor" -p
```

Output shows per-worker: session name, status, context %, current tool

### 3. Decision logic
Parse tmuxplexer output:
- `awaiting_input` â†’ User question pending, don't nudge
- `processing` / `tool_use` â†’ Working, leave alone  
- `idle` + issue still open â†’ Check worker pane for details
- Issue closed â†’ Worker done, can cleanup

### 4. Drill down only when needed
```bash
# Only if worker looks stuck, capture their actual pane
tmux capture-pane -t <worker-session> -p -S -50
```

## Benefits
- No separate watcher subagent
- Background window in conductor's session (not cluttering user's view)
- User can switch to monitor window via status bar if curious
- Single pane capture = all worker statuses
- Conductor retains full context for decisions
close_reason: Replaced watcher subagent with tmuxplexer background window polling. Created monitor-workers.sh script, simplified bd-swarm.md from 700 to 290 lines, moved watcher reference material to references/monitoring.md, removed watcher.md agent.

title: Add test-writing assessment to code-review workflow
description:
Code-reviewer agent should assess whether changes warrant test coverage and either write tests or flag for manual review.

## Current Gap
- No test writing in worker-done pipeline
- Complex changes ship without test coverage
- Bug fixes may lack regression tests

## Proposal
Code-reviewer outputs a `needs_tests` assessment based on:
- Complexity (cyclomatic complexity, lines changed)
- Risk areas (auth, payments, data mutations, API changes)
- Missing coverage (new functions/classes without tests)
- Regression risk (bug fixes that could recur)

## Possible Actions
1. **Auto-write tests** - For straightforward cases, generate test file
2. **Flag for review** - For complex cases, add to review comments
3. **Skip** - For trivial changes (docs, config, formatting)

## Integration Points
- `/code-review` command outputs `needs_tests: true/false`
- `/worker-done` pipeline runs test generation if flagged
- Or spawn separate `test-writer` agent for complex cases

## Example Output
```json
{
  "review": "LGTM",
  "needs_tests": true,
  "test_rationale": "New API endpoint with validation logic",
  "suggested_tests": ["unit test for input validation", "integration test for endpoint"]
}
```

title: Refactor conductor workflows into composable atomic commands
description:
## IMPORTANT: Create Backup First

Before refactoring, create a backup of the current conductor plugin state:
```bash
cp -r plugins/conductor plugins/conductor-backup-20260106
```

This ensures we can recover if the refactor breaks existing workflows.
design:
## Problem

Current `worker-done` skill is monolithic - all steps run together, hard to customize or swap implementations.

## Solution: Composable Commands

Each pipeline step becomes an atomic command in `plugins/conductor/commands/`:

### Proposed Atomic Commands

| Command | Purpose | Notes |
|---------|---------|-------|
| `/verify-build` | Run build, report errors | |
| `/run-tests` | Run tests if available | |
| `/code-review` | Opus review with auto-fix | Spawns conductor:code-reviewer agent |
| `/codex-review` | Codex review (read-only) | Runs `codex review --uncommitted`, cheaper |
| `/commit-changes` | Stage + commit with conventional format | |
| `/create-followups` | Analyze for follow-up issues | Important for research tasks |
| `/update-docs` | Check/update documentation | |
| `/close-issue` | Close beads issue | |

### Orchestrator Commands

`/worker-done` becomes an orchestrator that calls atomic commands:

```
/verify-build && /run-tests && /code-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue
```

### Example Compositions

```bash
# Standard completion
/verify-build && /run-tests && /code-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Quick completion (skip review)
/verify-build && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Codex review instead of Opus (cheaper, read-only)
/verify-build && /run-tests && /codex-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Research task (needs followups)
/verify-build && /code-review && /commit-changes && /create-followups && /close-issue
```

## Codex Review Details

Codex CLI v0.77.0 has purpose-built `codex review` command:

```bash
codex review --uncommitted -C $WORKTREE
codex review --base main -C $WORKTREE
```

- Inherently read-only (no --sandbox needed)
- Cheaper than Opus (~$0.02 vs ~$0.15 per review)
- Has access to Tabz MCP and Beads MCP
- Output is natural language (needs parsing to JSON for conductor)

### Trade-offs: Opus vs Codex Review

| Aspect | Opus code-reviewer | Codex codex-review |
|--------|-------------------|--------------------|
| Auto-fix | Yes (Edit tools) | No (read-only) |
| Cost | Higher | Lower |
| Speed | Slower | Faster |
| MCP access | Via Claude | Native |
| Output | Structured JSON | Parse NL to JSON |

## File Structure After Refactor

```
plugins/conductor/
â”œâ”€â”€ commands/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ verify-build.md      # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ run-tests.md         # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ code-review.md       # NEW atomic (wraps agent)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ codex-review.md      # NEW atomic (runs codex CLI)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ commit-changes.md    # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ create-followups.md  # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ update-docs.md       # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ close-issue.md       # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ worker-done.md       # NEW orchestrator
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ bd-swarm.md          # existing
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ ...
â”œâ”€â”€ skills/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ worker-done/         # can remove after migration
â””â”€â”€ agents/
    â””â”€â”€ code-reviewer.md     # keep for /code-review to spawn
```

## Benefits

- **Customization**: Mix & match commands for different workflows
- **Testing**: Test single steps in isolation
- **Swap implementations**: Use `/codex-review` instead of `/code-review`
- **Recovery**: Resume from failed step instead of re-running everything
- **New workflows**: Compose existing commands instead of writing new skills
acceptance_criteria:
0. **BACKUP FIRST**: `cp -r plugins/conductor plugins/conductor-backup-$(date +%Y%m%d)`
1. Each atomic command works standalone
2. `/worker-done` orchestrator calls atomic commands in sequence
3. `/codex-review` runs Codex CLI and parses output to JSON
4. Commands can be composed in different orders
5. Existing bd-swarm workflow still functions
close_reason: Refactored conductor workflows into composable atomic commands

title: Purpose-built agents with curated skills + skillsmp for agent creation
description:
Create purpose-built subagents for each workflow step, using skillsmp to curate the best skills during agent creation.

## Architecture

```
Workflow Step â†’ Slash Command â†’ Agent (curated skills in frontmatter)
```

Skills are baked into agents at creation time, not discovered at runtime.

## Agent Creation Workflow

When creating a new agent:
1. Identify what the agent needs to do
2. Search skillsmp for relevant skills
3. **Filter by stars** (default: >10 stars for quality)
4. **Niche exception**: For uncommon tech stacks, relax filter to include lower-starred skills
5. Preview top candidates, select best fits
6. Bake selected skills into agent frontmatter

```bash
# Default: popular skills only
curl "https://skillsmp.com/api/v1/skills/ai-search?q=terminal+rendering" | jq '.data.data[] | select(.skill.stars > 10)'

# Niche tech: include all
curl "https://skillsmp.com/api/v1/skills/ai-search?q=bubbletea+TUI" | jq '.data.data[:5]'
```

## Purpose-Built Agents

| Agent | Skills | Purpose |
|-------|--------|--------|
| `prompt-drafter` | pmux, code-review | Draft pmux-style prompts per issue |
| `worker-frontend` | ui-styling, web-frameworks, frontend-development | Frontend tasks |
| `worker-terminal` | xterm-js | Terminal/PTY tasks |
| `worker-backend` | backend-development, databases | API/server tasks |
| `worker-devops` | devops, docker-mcp | Infrastructure tasks |

## Slash Commands Per Step

| Command | Agent | Purpose |
|---------|-------|--------|
| `/plan-backlog` | plan-backlog | Analyze issues into waves |
| `/draft-prompts` | prompt-drafter | Generate pmux-style prompts |
| `/spawn-wave` | initializer | Setup worktrees, spawn workers |
| `/monitor-wave` | (script) | Poll worker status |
| `/complete-wave` | completion-pipeline | Merge, cleanup |

User runs each step to verify, or chains them.

## Skill Quality Filter

```
Default filter:     stars > 10 (quality guarantee)
Niche tech filter:  stars > 0  (include emerging skills)
Manual override:    user picks specific skill regardless of stars
```

## Benefits

1. **Verifiable** - User can run each slash command to see exactly what happens
2. **Curated quality** - Skills vetted via stars + manual review
3. **No runtime overhead** - Skills baked in, not discovered
4. **Composable** - Chain commands or run individually

## Source

## Opus 4.5 Behavioral Differences to Address

### 1. Tool Overtriggering
Opus 4.5 is more responsive to system prompts. Aggressive language may cause overtriggering.

**Find and soften:**
- `CRITICAL:` â†’ remove or soften
- `You MUST...` â†’ `You should...`
- `ALWAYS do X` â†’ `Do X`
- `NEVER skip...` â†’ `Don't skip...`
- `REQUIRED` â†’ remove or soften

### 2. Over-Engineering Prevention
Opus 4.5 tends to create extra files, add unnecessary abstractions.

**Add to relevant agents:**
```
- Avoid over-engineering. Only make changes that are directly requested or clearly necessary.
- Don't add features, refactor code, or make "improvements" beyond what was asked.
- Don't create helpers, utilities, or abstractions for one-time operations.
```

### 3. Code Exploration
Opus 4.5 can propose solutions without reading files.

**Add to relevant agents:**
```
ALWAYS read and understand relevant files before proposing code edits. Do not speculate about code you have not inspected.
```

Default outputs may look generic.

title: bd-swarm --auto: fully autonomous backlog completion
description:
Add auto mode to bd-swarm that orchestrates the entire backlog to completion without user interaction.

## Concept
`/bd-swarm --auto` runs until backlog is empty:

1. **Wave N**: Spawn workers for ALL ready (unblocked) issues
   - Each worker gets a worktree
   - All run in parallel
2. **Monitor**: Watcher handles review â†’ docs â†’ merge â†’ push
3. **Check**: When wave completes, `bd ready` for newly unblocked
4. **Repeat**: Spawn Wave N+1 for new ready issues
5. **Context check**: If conductor hits 75%, /wipe with handoff
6. **Exit**: When `bd ready` returns empty â†’ 'Backlog complete\!'

## Auto Mode Differences
- **No AskUserQuestion** - autonomous decisions
- **Wave-based parallelization** - all unblocked run together
- **Self-healing** - /wipe + beads = full state recovery
- **Runs to completion** - not just one wave

## State Recovery After /wipe
Beads issues contain all state:
- Which issues are open/closed/in_progress
- Dependencies (what's blocked)
- Worktree locations (in issue comments or naming)

Handoff just needs:
```markdown
## Auto-Swarm in Progress
Wave 3 of backlog processing.
Run `/bd-swarm --auto` to continue.
```

## Decision Making (No User Questions)
| Decision | Auto Mode Choice |
|----------|------------------|
| How many workers? | All ready issues (up to 5) |
| Which skills? | Match from context |
| Review failed? | Nudge worker, wait |
| Worker stuck? | Kill after 10min, requeue issue |

## Example Run
```
$ claude '/bd-swarm --auto'

Wave 1: Spawning 3 workers (TabzChrome-abc, def, ghi)
...workers complete...
Merged, docs updated, pushed.

Wave 2: Spawning 2 workers (TabzChrome-jkl, mno) [were blocked by abc]
...workers complete...
Merged, docs updated, pushed.

Context at 78% - running /wipe...
[session clears, handoff sent]

Continuing auto-swarm...
Wave 3: Spawning 1 worker (TabzChrome-pqr)
...worker completes...

bd ready: no issues
Backlog complete\! 6 issues closed across 3 waves.
```

title: Skip code review and tests for markdown-only changes
description:
The worker-done pipeline runs code-reviewer and test runner even when changes are only to .md files, which is unnecessary overhead.

## Current Behavior
- `/conductor:worker-done` always runs:
  1. Build verification
  2. Test runner
  3. Code reviewer
  4. Commit

## Problem
- Markdown-only changes (docs, CHANGELOG, README) don't need code review or tests
- Wastes API calls and time
- Research tasks that only update issue notes shouldn't trigger full pipeline

## Proposed Solution
Detect change types before running pipeline:

```bash
# Check if only .md files changed
if git diff --cached --name-only | grep -qvE '\.(md|markdown)$'; then
  # Has non-markdown changes - run full pipeline
  run_tests
  run_code_review
else
  # Markdown only - skip tests/review
  echo "Skipping tests and review for docs-only changes"
fi
```

## Files to Update
- `plugins/conductor/skills/worker-done/SKILL.md`
- `plugins/conductor/scripts/completion-pipeline.sh`

## Edge Cases
- Mixed changes (code + docs) should still run full pipeline
- Config files (.json, .yaml) should probably run review but not tests

title: Merge prompt engineering into conductor workflows, remove prompt-drafter
description:
## Problem

The current conductor architecture has a design flaw:

1. **prompt-drafter uses Haiku** - Haiku is not good at nuanced prompt crafting. Worker prompt quality matters.

2. **prompt-engineer is for Opus, but conductor IS Opus** - The conductor runs on Opus 4.5, so calling out to a separate prompt-engineer agent is redundant. The knowledge should be baked in.

3. **draft-prompts command adds unnecessary indirection** - Conductor should craft prompts directly as part of bd-swarm/bd-swarm-auto workflows.

## Current State

```
Conductor (Opus)
  â””â”€â”€ draft-prompts command
        â””â”€â”€ prompt-drafter agent (Haiku) â† Bad: Haiku crafting prompts
              â””â”€â”€ Returns prompt

prompt-engineer agent (Opus) â† Redundant: Conductor is already Opus
```

## Proposed Solution

```
Conductor (Opus)
  â””â”€â”€ Worker Prompt Guidelines (baked into workflow docs)
        â””â”€â”€ Crafts prompts directly using best practices
```

### Changes Required

**1. Merge prompt engineering best practices into conductor workflows:**

Add a "Worker Prompt Guidelines" section to bd-swarm.md and/or worker-architecture.md covering:
- Be explicit (Claude 4.x follows instructions precisely)
- Add context (explain WHY, not just WHAT)
- Plain text file paths (not @file references that auto-load)
- Skill hints as natural language triggers
- Success criteria format
- Avoid aggressive language (NEVER, MUST, CRITICAL)

Source content from: `plugins/conductor/agents/prompt-engineer.md`

**2. Update bd-swarm-auto/SKILL.md Worker Prompt Template:**

Enhance the existing template with the merged guidance. Currently:
```markdown
## Task: ISSUE-ID - Title
Description from beads...
## Key Files
- path/to/file.ts
## Guidance
Use the `/skill-name` skill for [specific aspect].
## When Done
Run `/conductor:worker-done ISSUE-ID`
```

Should include best practice notes inline.

**3. Remove or deprecate:**
- `plugins/conductor/agents/prompt-drafter.md` - Remove agent
- `plugins/conductor/commands/draft-prompts.md` - Remove command
- `plugins/conductor/agents/prompt-engineer.md` - Remove agent (content merged into workflows)

**4. Update references:**
- Remove references to draft-prompts from bd-swarm.md
- Remove references to prompt-drafter from any other files
- Update CLAUDE.md if it mentions these
design:
## Design Approach

### Where to put the merged content

Option A: Add to `references/worker-architecture.md`
- Already describes worker pattern
- Natural place for prompt guidelines
- Keeps bd-swarm.md lean

Option B: Add to bd-swarm.md directly
- All in one place
- But makes the file longer

**Recommendation:** Option A - Add "Worker Prompt Guidelines" section to worker-architecture.md

### Key content to preserve from prompt-engineer.md

1. **Be Explicit** - Claude 4.x follows precisely
2. **Add Context** - Explain WHY
3. **Soften Aggressive Language** - Avoid NEVER/MUST/CRITICAL
4. **Standard patterns:**
   - Plain text file paths (not @file)
   - Success criteria checklist
   - Completion command
5. **Anti-patterns to avoid:**
   - Vague adjectives
   - ALL CAPS
   - Negative framing

### Template evolution

Before (generic):
```
## Task: ID - Title
Description...
```

After (with guidance):
```
## Task: ID - Title

[Specific description explaining WHAT and WHY]

## Key Files
- path/to/file.ts (what to look at)
- path/to/pattern.ts (pattern to follow)

## Approach
[Explicit instructions - action verbs, not suggestions]
Use the `/skill` skill for [specific aspect].

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Specific measurable outcome
- [ ] Build passes
- [ ] Tests pass

## When Done
/conductor:worker-done ID
```

- [ ] prompt-engineer.md agent removed  
- [ ] draft-prompts.md command removed
- [ ] Worker Prompt Guidelines added to worker-architecture.md

- [ ] No remaining references to removed files

title: Create prompt-engineer subagent with Anthropic best practices
description:
Create a prompt-engineer subagent that helps write optimal prompts for Claude 4.x models.

## Reference
Anthropic official guide: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/prompting-best-practices

## Core Patterns to Include

### Be Explicit
- Claude 4.x follows instructions precisely
- Say "make changes" not "suggest changes" if you want action
- Frame with modifiers: "Include as many relevant features as possible"

### Add Context
- Explain WHY, not just WHAT
- Claude generalizes from explanations
- Example: "Your response will be read aloud by TTS, so never use ellipses"

### Soften Aggressive Language
- Replace "CRITICAL: You MUST..." with "Use this when..."
- Opus 4.5 is more responsive to system prompts, may overtrigger

### Thinking Sensitivity
- When extended thinking disabled, replace "think" with:
  - "consider", "evaluate", "believe"

### Standard Blocks

```xml
<default_to_action>
Implement changes rather than only suggesting them.
If unclear, infer the most useful action and proceed.
</default_to_action>

<investigate_before_answering>
Never speculate about code you have not opened.
Read relevant files BEFORE answering questions.
</investigate_before_answering>

<use_parallel_tool_calls>
If no dependencies between tool calls, make all independent calls in parallel.
</use_parallel_tool_calls>

<avoid_excessive_markdown_and_bullet_points>
Write in clear, flowing prose using complete paragraphs.
Reserve markdown for inline code, code blocks, and simple headings.
</avoid_excessive_markdown_and_bullet_points>

<frontend_aesthetics>
Avoid generic AI slop aesthetic.
Focus on: Typography, Color/Theme, Motion, Backgrounds.
Make creative, distinctive frontends.
</frontend_aesthetics>
```

### Anti-Over-Engineering
```
Avoid over-engineering. Only make changes directly requested.
Dont add features or refactor beyond what was asked.
Dont create helpers for one-time operations.
```

## Agent Structure
- Model: opus (for complex prompt crafting)
- Skills: sequential-thinking (for multi-step prompt design)
- Include the full reference guide in references/

title: Research skill-cortex-server for dynamic skill injection
description:
Evaluate skill-cortex-server MCP for dynamically injecting skills into conductor worker prompts based on beads issue context.

## Repo
https://github.com/Sim-xia/skill-cortex-server

## Concept
Instead of hardcoding skills per project, conductor could:
1. Search skill-cortex for relevant skills based on issue title/labels
2. Inject matching skills into worker prompts automatically
3. Access 28k+ skills from skillsmp.com database

## To Evaluate
- Code quality (currently 7/10 - decent but early)
- Integration with conductor skill-picker agent
- Performance of skill search at scale
- Whether to fork/extend or build similar
notes:
## Research Findings (2026-01-07)

### skill-cortex-server Overview

**Version:** 0.1.0 (early-stage)
**Stack:** Python 3.11+, MCP 0.9+
**Repo:** https://github.com/Sim-xia/skill-cortex-server

### Architecture

4 MCP tools:
1. `list_skill_tree` - Hierarchical skill browsing
2. `search_skills` - Text + tag search
3. `get_skill_details` - Fetch raw SKILL.md content
4. `update_tags` - Manage skill tags

Skills are scanned from filesystem (`~/.claude/skills`, `./.skills`).
No persistent cache - rescans on every startup.

### Skill Sources (via import script)

1. anthropics/skills (official)
2. agentskills/agentskills
3. huggingface/skills
4. ComposioHQ/awesome-claude-skills

### Comparison: skill-cortex vs conductor:skill-picker

| Feature | skill-cortex | skill-picker |
|---------|-------------|---------------|
| Skill count | ~100s (4 repos) | 28,000+ (skillsmp.com) |
| Search | Substring | AI semantic |
| Ranking | None | Star-based |
| Dependency | Local Python | External API |
| Indexing | Filesystem scan | None needed |
| MCP native | Yes | No (curl-based) |

### Code Quality Assessment: 6/10

**Pros:**
- Clean MCP implementation using FastMCP
- Proper data models (frozen dataclasses)
- Path traversal protection via index lookup
- Modular design (scanner, index_store, server)

**Cons:**
- No caching (rescans every time)
- Basic substring search (not semantic)
- Early version with limited testing
- Raw markdown returned without sanitization (prompt injection risk)

### Integration Verdict: NOT RECOMMENDED for replacement

**skill-picker wins because:**
1. 280x more skills (28k vs ~100s)
2. AI semantic search (much better relevance)
3. Star-based quality ranking
4. Already integrated with conductor

**skill-cortex could complement for:**
- Local skill inventory management
- Hierarchical browsing UI in dashboard
- Project-specific skills not on skillsmp

### Recommended Next Steps

1. **Keep skill-picker as primary** - No change needed
2. **Consider skill-cortex for local catalog** - Optional future enhancement
3. **If extending skill-cortex:**
   - Add persistent caching (JSON or SQLite)
   - Add skillsmp.com API as secondary source
   - Add semantic search via embeddings
   - Consider TypeScript rewrite for TabzChrome consistency

### Conclusion

skill-cortex-server is a decent MCP wrapper for local skill management, but skill-picker's connection to skillsmp.com provides far more value. No integration work recommended at this time.
